abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            unsatisfactory. This assessment is based on the fact that
            most of the physical components were not completed. However,
            both the Bank and the Borrower's performances achieved
            mixed ratings, since identification was satisfactory,
            consistent with the Government's strategy for the power
            sector. Yet, compliance with covenants was deficient, which
            contributed to the negative supervision results. The key
            lessons convey that: 1) Unconventional projects, require
            extensive research, adequate design, and if needed, a pilot
            project to precede the main operation. Therefore, the most
            appropriate lending instrument for this situation, is a
            Learning and Innovation Loan, which provides flexibility to
            changes, indicated by the successful Akosombo rehabilitation
            redesign, a best practice exceeding expectations. 2) Power
            diversification, a mix between hydro and thermal power
            supply, plus additional regional interconnection, could
            prove sustainable, particularly under uncertain hydrological
            conditions, as Ghana was faced with. Late action gave way to
            high energy costs, following the installation of emergency
            thermal power plants. 3) Independent regulation is critical
            if political influence becomes the cause for financial
            viability problems, such as the low tariffs in this project,
            which reduced the power authority's performance. Though
            an independent utility body has been now established,
            sustainability remains uncertain.

18151902.majtheme: Rural development,Urban development,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!: Ghana - Sixth Power Project (Volta River Authority)

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will ensure orderly sector
            development and will support VRA's investment program
            for the 1990 - 1995 period.  To this end the project will :
            a) maintain the high standard of reliability of the
            country's electricity supply; b) meet projected
            domestic and export demand through the year 1995, including
            an interconnection with Burkina; and c) implement its
            ongoing program of institutional development.  Project
            components comprise the following : 1) retrofitting of the
            Akosombo plant which includes the reconditioning of six
            turbine runners; 2) transmission development, including
            extensions of the 161 KV grid to supply the city of Wa and
            the provision of an interconnection with Burkina Faso; 3)
            provision of NED needs through 1994 for network extension;
            4) construction of a VRA training center; and 5) studies for
            future system requirements, tariffs and cooperation in power
            generation amongst neighboring countries.

docna.cdata!: Ghana - Sixth Power Project (Volta River Authority)

Ghana - Sixth Power Project
            (Volta River Authority)
